content:
Somebody changed the last input line of Test 5 from:
United, they'd face the night,
to:
United. They'd face the night,

I've restored the original input.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Pour dÃ©butants... mais il y en a tant, il en faut pour tout le monde.

Just to confirm: the constraints say the text can include numbers however, none of the test cases or validators do (unless I'm blind). Is this intentional as it 'can' include them, was this left in accidentally or am  I blind?
Did you write this poem as well?

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a good Clash of code

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not too bad even without regex.

"Text can contain upper and lower case letters, numbers, spaces and punctuation marks." So... pretty much anything? OK

"A punctuation mark can occur either in the middle or at the end of a word, but never at the beginning." This was a good suggestion, but it could imply that there are words like the possessives kids' and shoes' ending in an apostrophe. I'd suggest refining it further to *just* say they don't precede.

Goal / Solution
* Goal section mentions "y" as a vowel but your solution code doesn't treat "y" as a vowel.

Goal
* Please format each vowel (excluding the commas) as a constant.

* Please add the uppercase version of each vowel, or add a sentence about it.

* Please add:
Words are separated by a space.
Each word excludes any trailing punctuation marks.

Output
* Please add "in the same order as their appearance".

Constraints
* Please delete the second constraint. A constraint is a limitation on the possible range of inputs or outputs, and the second constraint is not that.

* Please add:
A punctuation mark can occur either in the middle or at the end of a word, but never at the beginning.

Cases
* If it makes sense, please swap Validator 3 with Test 1 so that Test 3 and Test 1 become a pair (they both have  input words starting with a vowel and containing punctuation marks). Alternatively, if the order is important, then please add a new validator to cover that feature.

* Currently some vowels in some letter cases (ignoring y/Y) are not covered in tests and/or validators:

   â€¢ E, U not in any tests
   
   â€¢ e, u, E, O, U not in any validators

Please add additional pairs of cases to cover them.

Thanks.
Changed it ! Is this better now ?
Ok! Changed it! Is it better now?
"A punctuation mark can never occur at the beginning of a word." Sorry, I meant something more like this.

Definitely better! I like the new cases!

Just one more typo to fix:

Output
* Please fix the typo: "rhier" => "their".

Thanks.
Oh yeah sorry for the mistake ! And I'm glad you like the new tests ðŸ˜Š
